revision.text:
{{For|Korean martial artist|S. Henry Cho}} {{Infobox person | name = Henry Cho | image = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1962|12|30|mf=y}} | birth_place = [[Knoxville, Tennessee]], U.S. | occupation = Comedian | years_active = 1986–present | associated_acts = | website = {{URL|henrychocomedy.com}} }} '''Henry Cho''' (born December 30, 1962) is an American [[stand-up comedian]]. His work can be heard nationwide several times weekly on [[XM Radio]]'s Channel 151, [[Laugh USA]], [[Sirius Radio]]'s Blue Collar Radio Channel 103, and [[Pandora Radio]]'s PG Comedy Radio Channel. Cho is notable for being one of the only Asian acts to appear regularly on the [[Grand Ole Opry]].
== Biography == Cho, who is of [[Koreans|Korean]] descent, was born and raised in Knoxville and went into stand-up comedy in 1986.<ref name=nguyen2010/> He attended [[University of Tennessee at Knoxville]], and moved to [[Los Angeles, California]] in 1989 to pursue his career, but always with the intent of returning to his roots in [[Tennessee]].
Cho often uses his childhood experiences as an [[Asian American]] in [[Southern United States|the South]] in his comedy. "I'm an Asian with a [[Southern American English|Southern accent]]," remarks Cho. "To a lot of people, that right there is funny."<ref name="nguyen2010" />
In interviews, Cho has stated that he is a practicing [[Christian]].<ref name=YoutubeIntvw/>
=== Career === Cho appeared on many television shows in the late 1980s and early 1990s, including ''[[The Arsenio Hall Show]]'', ''[[Bob Hope]]'s Young Comedians Special'', [[MTV]]'s ''1/2 Hour Comedy Hour'' and [[VH-1]]'s ''Stand-Up Spotlight''. His other TV credits include guest roles on various [[sitcoms]] such as ''[[Designing Women]]'', ''[[Lenny (television)|Lenny]]'', ''[[The New WKRP in Cincinnati]]'' and a starring role in the [[TV movie]] ''[[Revenge of the Nerds III: The Next Generation]]''. In 1994, after he moved back to Tennessee, Cho got a call from [[NBC]] to host a revamped version of ''[[Friday Night Videos]]'' titled ''Friday Night''. For two years, he commuted to Los Angeles weekly. More recently he appeared on ''[[The Tonight Show with Jay Leno]]'' and ''[[The Late Late Show with Craig Ferguson]]''. He was also the keynote speaker for the 59th Annual Radio and Television Correspondents' Dinner. Cho is well-known as a "clean" comedian, forgoing profanity and objectionable material,<ref name=palmer2014/> and has sometimes been referred to as "Mr. Clean".<ref name=belcher2013/>
He has appeared in three [[feature films]]. In 1997, he starred opposite [[Tom Arnold (actor)|Tom Arnold]] and [[David Alan Grier]] in ''[[McHale's Navy (1997 film)|McHale's Navy]]''. In 2001, he appeared in the [[Farrelly Brothers]]' movie ''[[Say It Isn't So (film)|Say It Isn't So]]'' with [[Heather Graham (actress)|Heather Graham]] and [[Chris Klein (actor)|Chris Klein]]. Most recently, in 2006, he appeared in ''[[Material Girls]]'' starring [[Hilary Duff|Hilary]] and [[Haylie Duff]].
During the holiday seasons of 2003 and 2004, Cho toured the U.S. with [[Amy Grant]] and [[Vince Gill]], appearing live during the couple's show.
In 2006, he had his own [[Comedy Central]] [[Television special|special]] entitled ''Henry Cho: What's That Clickin' Noise?'' in which [[Jeff Foxworthy]], [[Bill Engvall]], and [[Larry the Cable Guy]] were special guest voices in the opening scene.
In 2007, he signed a deal with [[Touchstone Pictures]] and [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] to write, produce, and star in a television [[situation comedy]] series centered on Korean-Americans living in the South. In 2009 he inked a deal with CBS/Paramount to write, produce and star in another sitcom with Craig Ferguson as executive producer. In 2011 Henry had a special/pilot "The Henry Cho Show" on [[Great American Country]] (GAC).<ref name=Cure2011/>
== Filmography ==
* ''[[Revenge of the Nerds III: The Next Generation]]'' ([[1992 in film|1992]]) * ''Bandit: Beauty and the Bandit'' ([[1994 in film|1994]]) * ''[[McHale's Navy (1997 film)|McHale's Navy]]'' ([[1997 in film|1997]]) * ''[[Say It Isn't So (film)|Say It Isn't So]]'' ([[2001 in film|2001]]) * ''[[Material Girls]]'' ([[2006 in film|2006]])
== Discography ==
* ''[[What's That Clickin' Noise?]]'' (2006; Warner Brothers/Comedy Central)<ref name=allmusic/>
== References == {{reflist|refs= <ref name=nguyen2010>{{cite web |url=http://www.asiaxpress.com/Articles/2010/mar/henry-cho-coming-to-comedy-works/1.html |title=Comedian Henry Cho comes to Comedy Works in Denver |last=Nguyen |first=Joe |date=March 17, 2010 |website=AsiaXpress.com |accessdate=2010-03-19}}</ref> <ref name=YoutubeIntvw>{{cite interview |last=Cho |first=Henry |title=Henry Cho Interview Series #3 |via=YouTube |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nX36M9vZwb0&list=PLAM3bXeQA1tf3VCNBhEe8iaEe4uJGreLm&index=3 |accessdate=2017-08-16}}</ref> <ref name=Cure2011>{{cite news |title=Knoxville native, comedian Henry Cho's new show to air tonight on Great American Country channel |date=September 8, 2011 |last=Cure |first=Sarah |newspaper=AL.com |url=http://blog.al.com/entertainment-times/2011/09/knoxville_native_comedian_henr.html |accessdate=2017-08-16}}</ref> <ref name=palmer2014>{{cite news |last=Palmer |first=Erica |title=Jim Gaffigan, Brian Regan, other comedians find that 'clean' works for them |newspaper=[[Deseret News]] |date=August 8, 2014 |url=http://www.deseretnews.com/article/865608287/Jim-Gaffigan-Brian-Regan-other-comedians-find-that-clean-works-for-them.html |accessdate=2017-08-16}}</ref> <ref name=belcher2013>{{cite web |last=Belcher |first=Josh |title=Henry Cho – Christian Man – Mr. Clean of Comedy! |date=November 18, 2013 |website=Rocking God's House |url=http://rockingodshouse.com/henry-cho-christian-man-mr-clean-in-comedy/ |accessdate=2017-08-16}}</ref> <ref name=allmusic>{{cite web |last=Jeffries |first=David |title=Henry Cho |website=[[AllMusic]] |location=Biography |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/henry-cho-mn0000980719/biography |accessdate=2017-08-16}}</ref> }}
